body:
Very partially resolves #3594 (See also for why this is PR exists).

The idea:
- Non-impeding, made to support as many things as possible.
- Non-destructive, mods using the old API should continue working unimpeded.
- Self-similar, made in the image of existing API classes.
- Portable, should still be compatible with fabric and forge

The concept:
- Each interface handler is stashed in a registry
- Calling `has(item)` on a registry checks if `item` implements the interface or has a registered handler in the registry.
- Calling `get(item)` on a registry retrieves the handler from the registry or `item` itself, preferring the implemented interface over the one stored in the registry.
- Registries can either be gotten directly from an instance of ItemAPI or from the handler interface (ex: `ISortableTool.registry()`)

**Why not capabilities?**
Attaching item capabilities to vanilla items or other mod's items is often tedious, impeding compatibility addon development. I'm not opposed to turning the item registries into item capabilities, but blocks must remain in this system as to my knowledge it's impossible to attach capabilities to blocks without tile entities.

**Non-functional interfaces should probably be tags**
Please advise on this point, it seems like it would be possible to turn ICosmeticBauble into a tag.

**Explicit empty checks**
Please advise on this point. Item registries could easily have get overloads added for ItemStacks that check for stack emptyness before querying the hashmap.

**Code example**
Old code:
```
if (stackItem instanceof IFlowerPlaceable) {
    success = ((IFlowerPlaceable) stackItem).tryPlace(this, ctx);
}
```
New code:
```
IFlowerPlaceable placeable = IFlowerPlaceable.registry().get();
if(placeable != null) {
    success = placeable.tryPlace(this, ctx);
}
```

body:
- provideBlock was not respecting doit=false as a full check of capability
 - getBlockCount providing a -1 sentinel for "infinite" is not accurate when the capability is in fact not infinite but dependent on mana availability.
 - Refactored a little bit in ManaItemHandlerImpl to avoid code duplication.
 - That refactoring revealed that requestManaForTool was un-discounting for some undocumented reason.  The function appears unused internally anyway, and I cannot think of any reason why it would undo the discount, so I nuked that.
commit_messages:
Fully implementing IBlockProvider on rods (#3577)

* Fully implementing IBlockProvider on rods

 - provideBlock was not respecting doit=false as a full check of capability
 - getBlockCount providing a -1 sentinel for "infinite" is not accurate when the capability is in fact not infinite but dependent on mana availability.
 - Refactored a little bit in ManaItemHandlerImpl to avoid code duplication.
 - That refactoring revealed that requestManaForTool was un-discounting for some undocumented reason.  The function appears unused internally anyway, and I cannot think of any reason why it would undo the discount, so I nuked that.

* Now with spotless

body:
this pr:

1. unhardcodes the ore weight "registry" by moving it to `.json`
2. relocates the initial weight processing to serverside datapack re/loading
3. ensures things like REI can access the data clientside
4. forcibly tags vanilla ores under the "common" `#c` namespace with vanilla-ish naming conventions used by other mods
5. due to the prior change, orechids now properly work on the fabric branch without further input; ~~though this pr will most likely clash with https://github.com/Vazkii/Botania/pull/3535~~

body:
The exception seen in current CI logs:

    > java.lang.Exception: You are running Spotless on JRE 8, which limits you to google-java-format 1.7
     If you upgrade your build JVM to 11+, then you can use google-java-format 1.9, which may have fixed this problem.

This is fixed by changing `FuzzyNBTIngredient.java` to actually contain a class. Now spotless can throw all of its formatting errors, which are fixed with `spotlessApply`.

The next error appears as various phrasings of "JVM out of heap space". Fixed by adding an Xmx arg to gradle.properties.

Finally, fabric-loom is upgraded to version 0.5 for the performance increase alleged in #3531.

Sorry about the 500 file commit. You're welcome to cherry-pick the other three commits and rerun spotlessApply yourself.

Significant things I see on first glance:
1. This interacts strangely with the new per-world bindings. This is bound to a player...but still per-world? What if the player is in another dimension?
2. This keeps the bound position essentially chunkloaded to check if it's a skull, which is not good.

Re: 1; If the player's in another dimension, the `getEntityByUuid` will just return `null` and you'll warp to the skull, afaik
Not sure how to mitigate 2 though
Currently no blockpos is saved when bound to a player anymore; this is so you don't see a wireframe when a skull breaks and gets replaced with another block
you know what, i've been reasonably convinced by the discord™ that this poses too big of a security risk. closing.

body:
Fixes #3426.

The current solution is to:

- make the whole thing static instead of per Entro because that's terrible all over

- always write the tag, write false if the TNT is ethical, true if it's unethical
- check if the TNT already has the tag before checking whether it's ethical
That should fix the issue ever coming up again, in worlds after this update.

However:
- worlds with Botania just added/updated with TNTs already in the world may still run into the issue

To circumvent that another check has been added:
- if the fuse is already below the max, don't bother checking

However this will still have issues from updating worlds with TNT's that haven't ticked at all since spawning.
comments: The new solution is to just check whether the chunk the entity is in is loaded.
Can you post your reproduction steps? I'd like to investigate myself. This current solution is open to exploit by just spawning TNT in lazy chunks to skip the ethical check, then loading it.
To reproduce, it's enough to place and ignite a TNT block, then reload the world.
I wasn't able to reproduce it this way.

re ^ reproduced by placing an entro first

as for this fix, yolo

body: Currently with only the Endoflame and the Kekimurus as generating flowers with categories, featuring very clunky and wordy translations.

The current Brew class is unable to create Brews using Effects that are registered through DeferredRegisters. By adding a supplier and modifying various fields to only use the EffectaInstance when needed through suppliers, Minecraft will not crash when trying to register a Brew using effects from other mods. 

I ran into this issue when I was trying to add brews when Botania is installed for my mod and am currently using a workaround to bypass the crash.
https://github.com/MinerArcana/Astral/compare/feature/botania_compat#diff-f4145c9694231af724e6a15feceb81e8
comments: After thinking about it, I realized the supplier in the alternative constructor was added to fix an issue with my mod where the effect instances were being stored as a list with effects that may not have been initialized when the brews were being registered. I could also make a variation that doesn't use a supplier in the constructor, but the switching the field to a supplier is still necessary to not crash.

body:
I came across this earlier today and was thoroughly annoyed when attempting to recraft in creative proved more difficult that it should be. Curretnly, reinserting a recipe required and removed the items from the player's inventory, creative mode or not. With this change, reinserting a recipe, while still requiring at least one of each item, no longer removes those items from the inventory.

![Runic Altar](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11538216/75280829-14c93480-5806-11ea-92ad-818d642da718.gif)
![Runic Altar 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11538216/75281261-dc762600-5806-11ea-9a2f-103b06019dc4.gif)
![Petal Apothecary](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11538216/75281307-f0218c80-5806-11ea-9919-33734804d127.gif)

Should reinserting a recipe from creative mode instead not require even the presence of materials?
comments: Reinserting recipes no longer requires any items on the creative player's part.

* Don't require any items at all if in creative.

body:
See https://github.com/Vazkii/Botania/issues/3180

Turns out the problem lied in the fact that only the OW state was being saved, and other dimensions', modded or vanilla, wasn't.
comments:
Hey, I was actually able to confirm this one this time.

[Video.](https://youtu.be/gL_tkQRFrGU)

this fix is confirmed to work?
As far as I could see when reworking the WSD in 1.13, it's all stored in the overworld anyways (all dims shared the overworld one)

Oh, looks like they got separated in 1.14. In that case, the proper fix for this is to actually separate all the pairs into their own dimensions, but that might be a bit sketchy for backwards compatibility.
This fix might(?) work as a stopgap, but it does redundant IO and needs to be tested so that there's no data loss for sure
the fix *seems* to work, it'll do until 1.15

body:
Add and run a Recipe Advancement Data Generator to allow for some recipe book support.

This isn't perfect, as some recipes don't work with the Data Generator and for some reason the Recipe Book sorts recipes by the Creative Tab the output is in instead of the folder the advancement is in, if you don't want to use this because of that feel free to close this PR.

Some blocks, specifically, **Mana Pools**, **Hopperhocks**, **Spreader Turntables** and **Force Relays**, have sneak-right click functionality for the Wand of the Forest. These functionalities could not be performed by dispensers, and I thought they should. This could potentially open up some new opportunities.

**Tests**

Switching Mana Pools from emptying tablets to filling them.
![prev1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11538216/73616571-fc059e80-460c-11ea-9d48-b92984a4f2f0.gif)
Cycling Hopperhock filter modes.
![prev2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11538216/73616918-1e012000-4611-11ea-9afc-74ce0c44ff91.gif)
Changing Spreader Turntable rotation speed and direction.
![prev3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11538216/73616919-1f324d00-4611-11ea-9beb-c873499feccb.gif)
Safely breaking a Force Relay.
![prev4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11538216/73616570-fc059e80-460c-11ea-94da-4ccc6d406e51.gif)

**Lexicon Changes**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11538216/73616593-353e0e80-460d-11ea-8250-d49e390bd366.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11538216/73616599-425afd80-460d-11ea-836f-9102755b2208.png)
(There's a typo on "a Mana Spreaders" here, third line)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11538216/73616601-4b4bcf00-460d-11ea-924e-edd826f4009c.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11538216/73616604-5999eb00-460d-11ea-8ca2-bda728879d38.png)
comments:
Bind mode to change speed and function mode to change direction seems a bit weird.
Maybe it should just cycle?

I thought it would be worth having the option for both, given that both are useful features. Then, I thought using bind/function mode would be a good way to differentiate between which to use, and have them both be available.
it just seems odd to shoehorn that into the bind/functional mode split

If you think so. I'd make it just switch direction, rather than cycle, if dropping one is necessary. Though I find the Bind/Function Mode split fitting:

You're *binding* it to a new speed, or changing its *function* in its rotation direction, perhaps.
Another way to choose between switching direction or speed would be to base it on the direction the dispenser is clicking from. Would this be better?

To make clear the change: a Dispenser with a Wand of the Forest from the side will change the speed, and one from the bottom will change the direction (as opposed to the bind/function distinction before).
@williewillus Vaz gave a go ahead on this, please review. (discord context: [link](https://discordapp.com/channels/154261184701267969/154261184701267969/675059805232300073))
commit_messages:
Dispenser Wand Functionality for Sneak-Right Clicking. (#3165)

* Update TilePool.java

* Break Force Relay with dispenser.

Why not?

* Hopperhock cycle filter type with dispenser.

This could lead to new functionality and could certainly not break anything.

* Reverse or change turntable speed with wand.

Reverse if in function mode, or cycle speed if in bind mode.

* Look who missed a parenthesis.

* Fix crash.

* Lexicon Additions

Since these actions normally require sneaking, it may be ambiguous whether a dispenser can perform it.

* Fix typo in Spreader Turntable entry.

* Side distinction rather than mode distinction for turntable.

actually, since this is an api class, you might want to move that TilePool method somewhere in the API and update calls to it. Feel free to put it wherever for now, the API needs to be cleaned up anyways.

~~Ok, I changed the method used, but given my limited knowledge of Botania's API I do not feel I am qualified to move classes around, I can't really say I feel comfortable changing more than I need to, although I could potentially just do a refactor in intellij. Should that not be in a separate change though, or do you think it should be bundled in this one?~~

EDIT: I actually realised what you meant after writing this, I will refactor tomorrow when I get the chance and move that method from TilePool to somewhere in the API. It's static anyway so it's easy to solve.

I got around this by adding a clock that pulses on the other side of the flower and gives it a block update, but i'm not sure how to solve that, since i'm new to mc modding. Also i am not sure whether the Lexica entry should be in the ender category as it currently is or in the alfhomancy one, feel free to leave feedback about that.

Also i will move it to the addon i am making for the Terra Harvester if i get told it won't get merged, but i was thinking i should at least try it here.

Edit: Also it wasn't even completely removed, most of the assets were still in botania.
I will move this to my addon in if it doesn't get merged until the next update.

body:
This Pull Request adds a Terra Harvester, a Terrasteel Shovel with the ability to harvest an 5x5 block area of Blocks that have the harvest tool shovel or crops.
It can also convert a 5x5 block area to Grass Path or Farmland and fertilize crops for mana.

**Other Changes:**
Moved the Terra Shatterer and the Terra Truncator in some Item Lists to get all Terrasteel Tools to the same place.

**Comments:**
The Textures aren't perfect but i think they are as good as i will get them.
comments: I don't know why it shows all the changes from Hubry's last commit as changes from this PR but i hope it doesn't causes problems.

The Terra Shatterer already covers this functionality.

Edit: See [ItemTerraPick.java#L69-71](https://github.com/Vazkii/Botania/blob/master/src/main/java/vazkii/botania/common/item/equipment/tool/terrasteel/ItemTerraPick.java#L69)

I know it kind of covers that but i think a cheaper shovel stuff only version would be nice some times.
Feel free to close this if you think it doesn't fits this mod.

Would be Vaz's call on whether to add it, personally I feel its not distinguishing enough from the already available options, currently its just an aoe manasteel shovel and has nothing that the shatterer cant do better.

When it comes the the shatterer and truncator they aren't just material upgrades, they have defining features that make that tier of tools have meaning, my thought would be to review what it is a shovel could do to provide something the others can't, it may be that you keep the aoe effect but it needs something to make it not just a crappier shatterer that only works on shovel things.

Also needs a different name, terrasteel grade tools have specific names (Terra Shatterer and Terra Truncator) not just [Material] [Tool Type] format, something like Terra Excavator or one that gives a good meaning to its abilities.

I was thinking about some other functionalities before i ended on this one, but i will think about other functionalities for it later today, maybe i find a better one.

I know this name doesn't fits the Tool i just didn't knew a really good one so i used this one as a placeholder, i will probably change it if i find a good functionality to match that.

The Texture is the only thing i don't have any ideas for.

For the texture I'd say maybe take the handle from the shatterer and stick a terrasteel head on it for now, maybe throw in the gem from the truncator, something like that.

you're missing images

Pollidisiac, Functional Intro, Endoflame, Enchanted Soil, Trinkets entries are grammatically correct afaik. Respectively:
 - Semicolon delimits two clauses; "Create a Pollidisiac" and "Get love in the air" are both valid (if short) sentences; semicolon it is.
 - 'Myriad' is an adjective as well as a noun.
 - 'Take' was used earlier, it's the implied verb in the absence of one; adding another 'take' just looks somewhat redundant
 - "to spell" is a bit iffier, but can probably be seen as "to enchant." I can change it to something else if you really think it looks odd.
 - Minecraft verbage doesn't quite have established conventions, but I think using "craft" as a transitive verb works here. Can change if you really think iffy.

body:
One issue I always had with Corporea Index requesting is that it often ends up requesting an item that has the same name, but isn't actually the same thing. Nether bricks, mushrooms, enchanted books are all good examples of it in 1.12. This PR makes keybind requests send an item stack.

* Keybind requests now send an itemstack instead of the item name. Items in inventories ignore their own NBT, JEI/recipe book items don't. The NBT matching was made less strict. (is full strictness desirable sometimes? This uses the logic from #2881.)
* Chat is no longer touched by keybind requests, fixes #2942.
* Recipe book buttons can now be a source of keybind requests, fixes #3052. 
* Keybind requests work again with shift and ctrl.
* Matchers are in charge of their index request formatting.
* Index event now uses a matcher (this and previous change break api).
* Indexes ignore spectators now.

body:
Two parts to this:
* If you moved the container away from its chest using something like Quark's piston pushing (looking at code, instead you could probably unload the chunk with the container but not the chest), the cap of the chest would be invalidated, destroying it and making the block incapable of doing anything not using IInventory. So we instead pack the cap in another optional. If it somehow gets destroyed without getting invalidated, the new optional gives an empty handler.
  * It's all cached so we don't create however many instances of lazy optionals every tick or anything, unless the thing you used it with doesn't cache its optionals. Please review this though.
* If you replaced the chest with another TE that doesnt have the item handler cap (for example, pushing the chest with a piston thanks to Quark), sparks would pop off, which is supposed to never happen nowadays, so we give out the empty handler.

Another option that I see is to add more similar changes to increase the complexity of the game and add one option in the configuration file "hardcore.enabled = false" to control all changes.

body:
* Created components for: 
  * a rotating list of items. Two variants are provided - one which takes a recipe, and one which takes a list of ingredient strings. The second one is basically only provided for modpack authors.
  * a mana bar. 
  * terra plate rendering. By default it renders the terra plate, but the blocks can be replaced with proper parameters. Required as blocks would weirdly overlap if stacked manually.
  * item list - created only because Patchouli will refuse to render air stacks as one of the conversion steps in item components is a conversion to an ingredient, which strips the air stacks from the rendered result. Marked deprecated.
* Created template processors for brews, elven trades, mana infusion, petal apothecaries, runic altars, and pages with multiple recipes on a single grid.
* Created templates for each of the above, as well as:
  * Lore pages - the background from old elven pages, as well as the elven garde seal page. The seal page is has a flipped background, and a flipped page without the small seal on the bottom is made for the left side.
  * Terrasteel - you can't just make a page with a custom arrangement of components without a template, so this is a template.
* Generator code now corrects camelCase names, accounts for multiblocks, and dumps lists of recipes as semicolon-separated lists, as component processors have a very limited access to the component json objects and cannot access lists.
* Very minor related tweaks - `IModRecipe#getId#; giving one petal recipe a group, minor tweaks to some lexicon entries, etc.

Things remaining:
* Assigning proper headers to all pages with multiple recipes
* Tying knowledge to advancements?
* Updating text in a few spots and tweaking pages, for example the head recipe would be switched to a link button page.
* Sorting recipes in places where they were ordered by something unstable like a tag
* Special reference features mentioned in README

Есть пожелание, проверяйте как будут выглядеть переводы, т.к. я стремился уменьшить количество слов, чтобы вписать текст в строки лексикона Ботании и в рамки всплывающих подсказок. поэтому приличная часть переводов звучит не по-русски :)
С вопросом написания "Вы" или "вы" всё достаточно неоднозначно. Например, по правилам русского языка нужно писать с маленькой буквы, по правилам современного бизнес-письма, наоборот, принято писать все слова "вы" с заглавной буквы, чтобы подчеркнуть значимость слушателя и чтобы прийти к мировым стандартам.
Другими словами, написание с маленькой буквы часто встречается в литературе, а с заглавной - в бизнес-письме. Теперь вывод: во-первых я за сохранение традиций русского языка, во-вторых, когда написано с маленькой буквы, читать легче, т.е. проще увидеть акцент на других словах, которые решил выделить Vazkii. Если есть желание, сделайте, как считаете правильным, ибо истины здесь нет и смысл переводов от этого не измениться.

body:
Some tedious recipe stuff, because I was annoyed by the giant amount of log spam related to recipe parsing and decided to silence most of it. In short:
* Item renames, mostly `word1word2` -> `word1_word2` or `silver` -> `light_gray`
* Data tag removed, uses migrated to flattened items/tags (floating flowers mostly) or NBT tagged items (flugel tiara)
* Register shapeless mana upgrade recipes and fluxfield condition, because those were missing. I hope they were not omitted on purpose.
* Lastly, JEI no longer gets raw block instances as recipe catalysts. (I threw in support for JEI bookmarks for the corporea index keybind too as it was just 2 lines.)

The only remainder now is the brass tag being missing on the cacophonium, but that's one stack trace per log compared to the ~80 from before.

body:
* Slightly less strict arena floor check.
  * In every column, you need a block one *or two* blocks below the height of the beacon.
  * (Or a block in both positions. But you need at least one.)
  * This lets you build an arena with the beacon base placed *on* the floor, instead of inset into the floor like the multiblock preview shows, which seems to be a popular method of building the arena after all (rel: #2897)
* Minor changes to accommodate for low-floor fights.
  * Block-breaking now happens only *above* the height of the beacon (== changed to >=, basically)
  * GG will move one block down if the chosen TP destination is floating in the air.
* Quality of life improvements to the arena check.
  * Improper pylons now show particle effects for where the pylons are supposed to go.

body:
My mod, [Demagnetize](https://minecraft.curseforge.com/projects/demagnetize), adds a Demagnetizer that disables magnets on items around it, like the Solegnolia. 
When I released the mod originally, I added support for Botania by [hackily](https://github.com/comp500/Demagnetize/blob/master/src/main/java/link/infra/demagnetize/blocks/DemagnetizerSolegnoliaCompat.java) emulating the Solegnolia, however this completely ignores the Whitelist/Blacklist functionality in my mod. Emulation of the Solegnolia also [breaks](https://github.com/comp500/Demagnetize/issues/1) this functionality in other mods' magnets that support the Solegnolia. I intended to submit a PR to Botania to improve this, but never got around to it.

To fix this, this PR adds a check for the boolean entity NBT tag `PreventRemoteMovement` in the magnet ring, originally standardised by Immersive Engineering and supported by almost all mods that add magnets. This will prevent the ring from working on items that have this tag. Immersive Engineering currently adds explicit support (through Botania's API) for preventing items on conveyors from being picked up by the ring, but after this is merged it will not be necessary; however it would be a bad idea to remove the compatibility from IE as it will break the functionality in older versions of Botania. A more thorough discussion of the `PreventRemoteMovement` tag and a related tag `AllowMachineRemoteMovement` was had [here](https://github.com/CoFH/Feedback/issues/1243).

An additional idea is that the Solegnolia could also add this tag (along with the `AllowMachineRemoteMovement` tag) to items in the area of the Solegnolia. This would significantly improve cross-mod compatibility for the Solegnolia, at the expense of changing the semantics of the Solegnolia. Currently, the Solegnolia prevents the magnet ring from operating when items or the player are in it's area. If the tag is added items will stay "demagnetized" forever, unless every item that has been in the area of a Solegnolia is kept track of and the tag is removed when they leave the area.

body:
See #2856, #2669. 
These two blocks aren't the fastest to tick, and the worst part of them is searching through the entire range affected by them, every single tick, only to use a few locations. This PR seeks to change that, making the search occur once every few seconds, and in the portal's case, whenever a pylon is broken. Also syncing exoflame data is pointless, so that is removed too.

The only difference in behavior is that detecting a placed pylon/furnace isn't instant, but it's not too slow to recheck the area. 
In case of portals, this change (measured manually with logging, because lazy, and also this testing is probably inaccurate because of JVM warmup) seems to divide the usual tick time by 4 (going from ~80μs to ~15μs, tested with 5 pylons), though scanning takes a bit longer (like 140-160μs). 
In case of exoflames, (tested with 10 furnaces), the tick time is about 10μs, and scanning the area takes ~100μs. It scales with the amount of furnaces - 25 raised ticktime to ~30μs, while having 0 of them is too low to properly measure.

Questions:
* willie mentioned `IWorldEventListener` on discord, would it be worth hooking into?
* tweaking the rescan period? Maybe a config?
* anything else to tweak?

Adds a simple method that lets a lexicon category say if it should be displayed in the category index. The use case is quat's addon Incorporeal adding enough Corporea stuff to justify moving it to a separate category, but that means displaying an entirely empty category if the lexicon isn't upgraded yet. Doing this externally involved some pretty ugly removal and rearrangement of buttons in the index.

@quat1024 Does this appear alright for you? 🤠

This PR adds locking of Corporea Crystal Cubes, modeled after the Hovering Hourglass lock.
* Sneak-using a Wand of the Forest on a crystal cube will lock the monitored item, preventing players from accidentally setting it to something else. Lexicon entry page included. This is shown on the contents render and sends a chat message to the player if they attempt to set it when locked. Locking can be done with dispensers, I made sure it properly syncs to players in that case.
  * Withdrawing items is not affected by the lock, in case that wasn't clear.
  * Why sneak-using and not just using the wand like the hourglass? Sooner or later someone will complain they can't put the wands there.
* Rendering of the overlay for runic altars, petal apothecaries and crystal cubes is disabled if someone is pointing a Lexica Botania at them. It looked pretty bad with overlapping stuff.
* Applied the same sync fix to the hourglass because dispensers pointed at the hourglass ended up desyncing that as well, making you think you can take out the sand when you can't. Yes I know it's very very very very useful to have a dispenser lock a hourglass on a timer.

How the render looks:
![obraz](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26120076/52733376-df6af380-2fc2-11e9-8a12-2c50d8df9e08.png)

body:
This PR changes a few things relating to the Gaia Guardian. It fixes some cheesy bugs and cleans up the code a little bit.

* Fix #2586 by preventing sleeping during the fight and waking up any players who are.
* Change the Gaia Guardian arena check to be far stricter. It needs an unbroken floor and at least 5 blocks of clearance above the floor. [Here is a diagram](https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/404671932072591380/545045764934729759/unknown.png), the yellow blocks are the ones the GG checks (lowest layer = needs to be soild, other layers = needs to be nonsolid)
* A few code cleanups (add a few section comments, clean up `par1nbtTagCompound` cruft)
* Change the way the GG handles teleportation.
  * Instead of sharing TP code with endermen, it simply randomly picks a point inside the arena to teleport to.
  * Liquids and nearby collision boxes do not faze the guardian anymore.
    * (This fixes the "carpet exploit".)
  * Code has been cleaned up re this, and all of the relevant teleportation logic has been moved into one method.
* The GG now breaks nearby blocks:
  * every tick around itself
  * and along the line of which it teleports.
  * It does not break blocks on the floor or in pylon columns, unless they are "cheaty blocks".
  * With a new API method, modders can specify blocks that the GG will not break, e.g. if an addon adds special pylons or something to spice up the gg fight.
    * The default ignored blocks are pylons and beacons, of course.
    * Hey williewillus, I didn't forget to bump the API version this time!
* Fix #2824 by not trusting the heightmap for the positions to spawn magic landmines at.
  * It now just always places them at the height of a random player.

Things to possibly think about:

* I removed an override of `EntityLivingBase#attemptTeleport` while cleaning up random teleportation code.
  * Vanilla only uses it for endermen TP and chorus fruit TP. Are there any mods that call this method that could cause problems?
  * The worst that would happen is the GG teleports outside the arena and ends the fight prematurely.
commit_messages:
Gaia fixes and anticheese stuff (#2853)

* No sleeping through the fight!

* Far stricter arena check

* Some cleanups

* Change the way GG teleportation works + happier to break blocks

* Simplify teleportation logic.
  * Basically just picks a point somewhere in the arena and goes there.
  * Doesn't take collision boxes etc into consideration.
  * This fixes the "double carpet" exploit.
* GG is now super happy to break blocks.
  * Will break blocks in the path of a teleport.
  * Will break blocks around it every tick.
  * A new API method is added to add immune blocks (such as the pylons).

* Fix #2824 by always spawning traps at the arena height

* Fix regression where the gg considered players in spec mode

* Fix landmines better

* Fix block break position lol

body:
This is an upstream fix of this issue in Botania Tweaks: https://github.com/quat1024/BotaniaTweaks/issues/42

The idea is that when an item has an NBT tag in a recipe, items must have *at least* those NBT tags. In other words, the NBT tag on the recipe item has to be a subset of the NBT tag on whatever item the player throws in. This makes it ok to not specify *all* the nbt tags *ever* on an item when writing recipes, which is what players would expect anyways.

However, previously this did not work properly with nested tags. An item with a tag like `{out:{in:1,extra:2}}` would match a recipe with a tag like `{}`, but would not match `{out:{in:1}}`. This creates problems when trying to create recipes for items with lots of weirdly structured NBT data (the use case in the original issue is bees lol `oof`)

I broke this code out into a separate function, too, so I can call it from btweaks next time we both update, and stop duplicating it.
comments: i wonder if vanilla/forge's nbt ingredients are susceptible to this? I'm looking into moving to those in 1.13.
tbh when writing this, I get the impression that this isn't exactly a rare problem but wasn't really able to find any methods that matched nbt tags in this way

Bees are an odd case. The nested tags include a list tag, and neither the old approach nor the new one will do a subset comparison on two list tags. To rewrite your example: an item with `{out: ["in", "extra"]}` should match a recipe with `{out: ["in"]}`. There's a reason why list tags *shouldn't* be allowed to do a subset (or rather, startswith) match, but I can't quite put it into words right now.

body:
see #2795 

An unintended side effect of unlocking the Apothecary is that, if you immediately refill the Apothecary after crafting a flower (a common way to automate it), the flower would just go in the apothecary instead of being collectable.

This PR fixes it by tagging item entities that the Apothecary spawns and making the Apothecary ignore item entities with the tag.

(It's not impossible to automate the apothecary even without this fix, since you can leave it empty by default instead of full by default. But it's definitely kind of silly to enforce one method over the other.)
comments: this is a pretty oof oversight, it's gonna break automated builds so we should get this out asap

body:
Vazkgoo asked for a few Botania Tweaks things to be merged in, since I'm also happy with the state of these features and think they might fit well in mainline Botania... hi, here's a PR with a million unrelated things in it :disappointed:

One thing per commit, let's go:

* A big buff to the Spectrolus (before: 300 mana/wool, now: 2400 mana per wool, **8x** increase). 
  * This is one of my favorite flowers, but I always thought the mana you got from it wasn't worth the effort since you needed a huge amount of wool to do much of anything. Kind of like the Rafflowsia before it got a similar big buff
  * A single piece of wool is now worth twice as much as a single piece of charcoal in an Endoflame, compared to 1/4 as much. I think this is fair, considering how hard it is to obtain, dye, and dispense wool, compared to running a very easy mana generating tree farm and just mindlessly drizzling the results over a bunch of endoflames
  * Rainbow status: Tasted.
* Gunpowder to flint is now the same price as flint to gunpowder.
  * This makes it possible to run an Entropinnyum off a cobbleworks by conjurationizing gravel, breaking it until you get 5 flint, alchemizing the flint into gunpowder, alchemizing 4 cobble into sand, and crafting them together into TNT.
  * Previously the flint-to-gunpowder recipe was too expensive to get 2 gunpowder back from a TNT explosion.
* Petal apothecaries now allow whatever you want in them.
  * The glitter particles default to grey if none are assigned via implementing `IFlowerComponent`.
  * I replaced the now-obsolete `IFlowerComponent#canFit` with a deprecated default function.
  * ...And added a few `//TODO 1.13`s since jaysus this name doesn't fit at all now.
  * Packmakers love this feature btw :wink: 
* Apothecaries and altars can NBT-match their items.
  * Basically the user specified item has to have at least all of the NBT tags that the recipe specified item has.
  * Check `RecipePetals#compareStacks`.
  * Nothing in Botania itself uses this feature right now, but it proved to be pretty popular with packmakers too

body:
Mana spreader code is lovely as we all know so I'd like to get a few more eyes on this, if at all possible? (And someone who knows how to use a profiler would be really nice, ha!)

This PR:
* caps the maximum mana burst beam-scan distance to 400 ticks into the future, preventing big lags from https://github.com/Vazkii/Botania/issues/2787
  * This changes gameplay behavior but nobody will actually care
* stops beam-scan mana bursts from searching for entities (this information was simply thrown away, resulting in lots and lots and lots of wasted calls to `getEntitiesWithinAABBExcludingEntity`)
  * The Tripwire lens still works btw
* stops beam-scan mana bursts from sending "pings" to the mana spreader - this information was also simply thrown away, resulting in a lot of useless calls to `getTileEntity`
  * This is something I am unsure about, maybe something breaks here.
* comments out "inWater" related code from all mana bursts - I was never able to make a mana burst actually appear `inWater`, no matter how I aimed it at a pool of water.

Potential future areas of spreader/burst optimization (read: maybe don't merge yet?):

* is PositionProperties a hot spot? lots of little allocations there I'm sure
* what about `getLensInstance`?
* `onEntityUpdate` seems to be doing a *huge* amount of useless things. Running particles? Riding entities? Fire damage? DEFINITELY check this out. Lots of stuff that's not really that bad on its own but when you have a bunch of mana bursts doing these pointless checks every tick + spreaders occasionally doing 400 or so in a single tick... it can add up

Feel free to look in to any of those areas - I'll probably do it myself later when I get the time, but it's like 2:30am
comments:
Similiarly to `inWater` you could probably comment out the glowing parts (I tried to manually set a burst to glow and it didn't seem to do anything, I guess because there's nothing to render, just some particles) and `throwableShake` (seems entirely unused for EntityProjectile).

Overriding things `onEntityUpdate` calls is probably a good idea - make running particles and water movement etc. no-ops and make sure it never can be on fire I guess.

Can we make the lens stack and the used lens a variable or something instead of reading it from the data manager every single time? That would likely reduce deserialization overhead from reading the stack so many times, and maybe #1977 could finally get closed? 

Is it worth hooking the max simulation tick time into a config option? Obviously the upper limit would not be crazy large and the lower limit should stay around this value, I'm just afraid someone is using a weird setup with something like triple Resistance lenses for some reason and it times out after 400 ticks and we will hear angry complaints.

1. I would recommend against overriding things randomly to noop them unless it produces a real, measurable impact. It's more to maintain and keep track of when porting
2. If I recall correctly, the data manager already stores things in deserialized form internally, so this wouldn't help much
3. Yes, the simulation time should be configurable I think.

Profiling definitely is a good idea and Quat actually wanted to do that before doing more in this area (and I had to remind him of the profiler again).

Anyways, I did a little bit of profiling with Spark with the latest Botania release. Small testing setup of: 3 mana spreaders with resistance lenses pointing directly into a chain of 7 resistance prisms, with 7 blocks of space before a wall. 
For client thread profiling, held a wand of the forest and did `/sparkclient start --include-line-numbers --timeout 60 --interval 1` while looking at the setup.
For server thread profiling, set up a few pistons moving blocks just before the wall on a 3 second timer and did `/spark start --include-line-numbers --timeout 360 --interval 1`.

[Client results](https://sparkprofiler.github.io/#Zn9AiHZL5z), [server results](https://sparkprofiler.github.io/#f9sklj71Yt).
Seems like checking if the burst is in lava, entity search as well as all data manager calls combined are somewhat heavy (seems like data manager might be the heaviest thing when all the calls are added), while PositionProperties has a negligible impact. I'd say no-oping some of these things I mentioned might be a viable option.

Vazkii likes it so we're going to merge it pretty much as-is, hope that's okey:eyes:

I added a configuration option for the spreader trace time (there's no min or max value on it, I can trust people to be sensible here :stuck_out_tongue: ).

I also nooped `isInLava` since it's a pretty free fix for a relatively expensive function (according to Hubry's profiling about as bad as the pointless `getEntitiesWithinAABBExcludingEntity` checks, ouch)

> I would recommend against overriding things randomly to noop them unless it produces a real, measurable impact. It's more to maintain and keep track of when porting

Good point - I added a comment to the `isInLava` override to hopefully explain why it's there and I'll be more careful about this type of thing ifwhen I revisit optimizing.

comments: Скажите, пожалуйста, каким образом определяется где писать большую букву в названиях предметов? Вы берёте с английского файла?

Доброго времени суток. Про что именно идёт речь? Хотя и без ответа на этот вопрос можно пояснить. Дело в том, что американцы любят писать все слова в названии с большой буквы, за исключением or, the, in, to и т.д. У них свои правила, у других свои, но в каких-то моментах эти правила всё же совпадают. Посмотрите на другие переводы и вики-проекты, чтобы убедиться в этом. А ещё лучше посмотреть на перевод самого майнкрафта. Вы видели в русском языке блоки и предметы, где каждое слово пишется с большой буквы? Я думаю, нет. В русском языке с большой буквы принято писать первое слово предложения и имена собственные, а ещё не стоит забывать о местоимении "Вы". Кроме того, иногда бывают исключения, о которых Вы можете почитать в интернете

body:
* Add brew aspects, generated from the potion's ingredients similiarly to vanilla potions.
* Add Spectrolus aspects, as I missed that one...
* Tweak a few aspect lists.
* Move TC brew recipes to init - registering them in postinit was too late to assign aspects to the brew, as aspect registration is done in Thaumcraft's postinit which runs earlier. Should not have any side effects.
* Replace wood and stone stacks with their aspects, avoids livingwood having just Victus in some modpacks.
* Reduce the amount of wildcard metadata, which can rarely cause some minor issues with items not having expected aspects and is just unnecessary for many things.
* Remove aspects from entities that are just entity form of items. I was getting annoyed around Corporea sparks when using my Thaumometer.

Beta 26 added some new stabilizer mechanics and I am wondering if it is worth messing with (for example, tweaking the effects pylons have on infusion), but I am not sure what are his plans with that part of the API, so leaving that alone for now.

body:
`damageDropped` is called by `EntityFallingBlock#onUpdate` in the event that the falling block must drop as an item, causing the Metamorphic Stone to drop its cobble variety after being struck by a Weight Lens.

This patch changes the stone to implement `getDrops` instead of `damageDropped` to drop cobble varieties as needed. Now, cobble varieties are dropped when the block is broken by a non-Silk pickaxe, and smooth varieties dropped using a Weight Lens.

comments: I might be dumb but how does this prevent that?

Regen III applies healing whenever the effect duration is modulo 6. If the duration starts at 60, it heals on the first tick. Then GG removes the effect, the Kanade reapplies it, and it ends up healing on *every* tick.

body:
A minor nitpick PR, I guess.

Llamas were added in 1.11, while parrots were added in 1.12.
Both of them are a rare pet and so should be available from the cocoon. I assume the only reason they were not available is that no one actually thought about it. The last functionality change of the cocoon was adding shulker spawning in early 1.11.

This ensures that GoG players will be capable of obtaining these mobs, possibly giving access to some parts of other mods as well.

This does make the other rare mobs slightly rarer, but while I did think about buffing the rare mob chance slightly, I doubt this will matter too much in the long run as reliably getting a pair of all the rare mobs already requires a decent investment, but I am open to tweaking the numbers.

Oh, there were some talks in Vazkii's discord about making this more dynamic but I decided it would be a bad idea because who knows what weird entites other mods add...

body:
This is a little PR that helps me get rid of a *lot* of hackery in Incorporeal.

- adds `InventoryWrapEvent`, fired when the corporea system wraps an inventory, and allows for replacing the `IWrappedInventory` instance
- adds `CorporeaIndexRequestEvent`, fired just before a player requests an item from a corporea index; cancellable, for a feature I have that allows for denying specific players access to a corporea index
- changes some `private` things in `WrappedIInventory` to `protected`, just so I can extend it more easily (beforehand I would just extend `WrappedInventoryBase` and duplicate a lot of the logic)

I do feel kinda weird about adding events and stuff that, realistically, isn't going to get much use outside of my mod. Especially making addons to the corporea system which just piles on more technical debt. But hey.
comments:
is it possible to instead add an interface (either directly used by TE's or exposed as a cap) that TE's can implement/provide to allow corporea access to them?

botania's API doesn't usually do this kind of thing with events, using interfaces is the convention here.

This is true - I *kinda* want to move away from interfaces all over the place since something something Forge 1.13 removing `@Optional`, but this isn't really the place to be doing it...

One trick with `wrapInventory` is that `InvWithLocation` is just an item handler with a position, no tile entity. I'd rather have people apply their `ISpecialWrappedInventory` interface to their tile entity (or even to their block), but that would involve a lot of changes, since by the time `wrapInventory` is called the specific tile entity that the inventory belongs to is long gone, and while a world/pos is available, doing `getTileEntity` *again* is kinda silly.

I've reverted those inventory wrap changes for now, maybe it needs more excavating than I thought.

One other thing I wanna look at btw is crafty crates. Botanka tweaks's custom crafty crates are really annoying to implement; because tilecraftcrate is nearly impossible to extend I opted to extend tileopencrate and just reimplement the crafty crate stuff. Hmm

body:
The comparator signal strength of the corporea retainer is now larger for larger requests. The math is exactly the same as the corporea crystal cube - it starts at one, and each step up needs double the item count.

This will probably break a few redstone contraptions, but it's easy to fix by just putting a repeater in front of the comparator.

Originally this was a patch in my addon Incorporeal but it doesn't really belong there.
comments: if the intention's to keep the math the same between the two, extract it to a common method and have both call it

This is true, I blame still being in "patch as little as possible mode"

Will close in favor of a new pr

body:
Resolves #2629. I hope Willie is still interested in adding aspects!

This PR changes the following:
* Thaumcraft 6 is now pulled directly from Curseforge. The alternative was dumping the whole TC6 API into the api folder in the repo, because adding aspects requires referencing the ThaumcraftApi class, which references a whole lof of stuff, so good luck with compiling. (Removed the marker interfaces from the api folder while I were at it.)
* Made upgrade recipes move attached Thaumcraft item data properly. While infusion enchantments (and, by extension, warping) are not yet available on armor, that's probably coming at some point, as you can see some starts of armor enchantments in Thaumcraft's internal classes.
* Fixed full mana inkwells pulled from creative menu not working. They were just missing the mana tag and Thaumcraft thought they were empty for that reason.
* Blacklisted flux rifts instead of (removed) aura nodes from Rod of the Shaded Mesa.
* Cleaned up a few TODOs around Thaumcraft integration.
* Finally, assigned Thaumcraft aspects to Botania items!

### Aspects

This was probably the most time consuming task and I am still not fully satisfied with it. I tried to assign aspects to the base items and things that don't get them automatically generated, but in the end I at least added aspects to the default assignment for a lot of stuff.

I did reference Wire's aspects from Botanical Addons (see the issue linked on top), however since Thaumcraft had some pretty big changes done to the aspect list and other things since TC4 (a lot of aspects no longer exist and items contain a lot more essentia nowadays), I had to do my own thing for a big majority of items. I also use autoassigned aspects a lot more.

I waited with this PR for Beta 17, as that one fixes items containing NBT ignoring aspects assigned to items with no NBT. Turns out a lot of items, including every single Botania bauble, get at least an empty tag the moment you press Shift while looking at it.

I only noticed one real issue - white petal powder doesn't have Herba I assigned to it and white petal blocks don't have any aspects. Haven't noticed anything else weird other than that.

I'm open to feedback about the assigned aspects.
Oh, and before someone asks, the twigs have only 8 Herba because I wasn't a fan of how every item made with them had like 30 to 60 Herba. That aspect is way too common anyways.
comments: looks good, we can improve the aspects in a separate pr
And as it got merged I noticed spaces sneaked in in some spots for indentation. Oops. If I make a followup I'll fix those... 😓
commit_messages:
Update Thaumcraft integration (#2667)

* Pull TC6 from Curseforge's maven thing, remove API classes from repo

* Update Thaumcraft integration

* Make upgrade recipes move attached Thaumcraft item data properly
* Fix full mana inkwells pulled from creative menu not working
* Blacklist flux rifts instead of (removed) aura nodes from gravity rod
* Clean up a few TODOs around Thaumcraft integration
* Finally, assign Thaumcraft aspects to Botania items

* Add config for aspects.

Just in case of some bugs in Thaumcraft, or for modpack makers who want
to customize, so they don't have to disable everything by hand.

body:
I noticed a lot of outdated links in the wiki provider list, going to sites that are gone or taken over by some shady stuff, and decided to clean that up a bit.

No new wikis were added - basically the main reason I did this was being afraid any users would accidentally use the lexica on a block and land on a bad site.

Summary of changes:
* Gamepedia is now purely on HTTPS
* Lowercased the modids. Didn't change that the providers lowercase the modid as well - what if someone's using the API expecting that? (as if anyone uses this feature).
* Buildcraft's wiki previously used doesn't exist anymore.
* Ars Magica 2, Pneumaticraft - the site was taken over last time I checked.
* Witchery, Gany's mods - those mods seem to be entirely dead. 
* Steve's Carts, Random Things - both were on wikispaces, which stopped being free a while ago... and they are shutting down this year. Random Things migrated, but Steve's Carts doesn't have a wiki anymore.

One thing I didn't address was Big Reactors - the fork Extreme Reactors has a few changes, including appending ` (Legacy)` to the block names, for example. I am not sure if it even uses the same modid as Big Reactors.

body: Sorry for breaking the original order，but this is a huge update which fixed a lot of old problems.

In Garden of Glass without fancy sky rendering, dipping below y=63 or so makes the sky go dark. I looked into why that is, given that in the "Void" superflat preset in Minecraft this does not happen. This is because that preset uses the "Void" biome everywhere. Using any other biome causes the same dark sky problem below where the ocean should be.

This takes the settings from the "Void" biome and hopefully applies them to all biomes when in Garden of Glass, i.e. using the "botania-skyblock" world type. Not sure whether sea level should be changed as well.
comments: Mods like to do funky things depending on the sea level, so probably safer to just leave it at the default. this is good though, thanks

body:
When the Munchdew is done eating leaves, it goes on cooldown for 80 seconds, then is supposed to return to an idle state and wait for more leaves to appear.  Instead, if it comes off cooldown and finds no leaves for 5 ticks, it goes back on cooldown.

This PR fixes this issue by setting the ateOnce field, which controls whether the Munchdew goes on cooldown when there are no leaves to eat, to false when the flower enters its cooldown.  Alternately, this could be done inside the `if (cooldown > 0) {...}` block.
comments: I like it in the cooldown > 0 block more, but thanks for the explanation/PR!

Consolidate all age checks done by functional and generating flowers
(and the Open Crate) into a new class, ItemAgeHelper. These age checks
ensure generating flowers act on dropped items before functional ones,
ensure that items newly created by Mana Infusion are not acted upon
immediately by either flower type, and conveniently move all of the
magic age numbers into a single place.

This also changes the Pollidisiac, Rannuncarpus, and Spectranthemum to
delay acting upon items newly crafted by Mana Infusion.

Fixes #2195

body:
This is mainly for items dropped by the game that are set to no despawn (age = -6000). Proposed solution is to add the item's lifespan to the age if the age is found to be negative.

Reading through the EntityItem code, the only time age is set to negative is when setNoDespawn() function is called or age is set to -32768 which in this case age will never be incremented and the default lifespan value is not sufficient to bring the age to positive values.

Tested and it works. Fixes #2018.

body:
Make getTileEntity safe from getActualState and getExtendedState, closes #1999

The problem:

* getActualState and getExtendedState can be called from other threads
* getTileEntity by default tries to create the TE if it doesn't exist (??? vanilla)
* this creation can CME the main thread

The solution:

* Insert special case to use a version of getTileEntity that doesn't try to create if it doesn't exist. The code for this special case is basically straight out of `BlockFlowerPot.getActualState`, so I trust that mojang knows that that works :P

body:
Botania currently is compiled against 1.9.4 mappings, yikes! (My fault...).

This PR updates the whole mod to the latest stable 1.10.2 mappings, stable_29. No functional changes, just renames.

Coincidentally, a bunch of these renames are also in 1.11, so here's, like, 12 to 25% of your 1.11 update :P 

There's a problem here though: Baubles 1.10 is compiled against older MCP mappings, and FG can't remap dependencies if they don't come from Maven. So setting up a 1.10 environment means you now have to take the obf 1.10 Baubles and run BON2 on it to get a Baubles-deobf with new mappings. A few extra steps but don't know if anyone would mind, and this is just to set up a 1.10 env right now. The problem goes away in 1.11. Seeing as any more 1.10 builds seem unlikely you can just treat this as an initial portion of 1.11 :P

They both represent the amount of ticks the EntityItem existed except that the EntityItem class has some magic numbers for age to represent certain item states.

body:
Allows using a Lexica as an ingredient in Alfheim Portal recipes.

This is required for my Elven Charter addon which uses the Lexica to track who's used the current trade and who hasn't.

To address willie's concerns on my original PR for this (williewillus/Botania#421), `isElvenItem` doesn't work for this without modifying and changing the meaning of the method. Currently `ItemLexicon.isElvenItem` return `true` if the elven knowledge has been unlocked, so the Lexica can't be thrown back into the portal. This would require special casing in the Portal or changing the fundamental meaning of `isElvenItem`, potentially breaking anything else that uses it.

body:
This pull allows armor sets that grant a mana discount (or mods that add a discount through ManaDiscountEvent) to change the discount based on the item in use. This would enable armors that only grant a discount to certain rods, or certain tools (or give an increased discount for certain rods or tools).

For example, one could implement a "fire" armor set that would grant a 50% discount to the fire rod but 10% to other rods.

body:
**Changes:**
Adds two helper functions, getManaItems() and getManaBaubles(), in ManaItemHandler so that the code for gathering mana-storing items no longer needs to be repeated in ManaItemHandler and HUDHandler and to enable ManaItemsEvent to function.

getManaItems() gathers mana-storing items from the player's base inventory, as base Botania does. The new code here calls ManaItemsEvent to enable mods to pass (or remove) mana-storing items from their own inventories.

getManaBaubles() gathers mana-storing items from the player's baubles inventory. The reason this function is separate from getManaItems() is because Botania code requires sendBaubleUpdatePacket to be called when a mana-storing bauble is accessed. sendBaubleUpdatePacket needs a slot number as a param, so I had to make this.

**Potential uses:**
Locations in which mana-storing items can be accessed is no longer fixed to just the base inventory and baubles inventory. This enables a variety of scenarios:
- Mana-storing items placed in additional inventory or equipment slots added by other mods can now be accessed by Botania items
- Cyberware items can be used to store mana
- Mods can selectively disable certain mana-storing items by removing them from the list passed in ManaItemsEvent. Not sure how this could be used - maybe a potion effect that disables mana tablets or something.

Fixed some code that was definitely buggy. Possibly solves #1825

Why it was buggy? Checking for mc.thePlayer != null and then before analyzing the result calling !mc.thePlayer.isSneaking() in the same expression is not a good idea. But you have more experience with Java than I do, so you know... you probably just missed this.
comments:
No, her code is fine. Yours is a mess, though. 
@yrsegal , so please tell me what would happen if you run her code and mc.thePlayer returns null?

For as far as I know, Java always evaluates every single part of a boolean expression. (Except if an exception or error is thrown of course.)

So evaluating (a && b && c) would evaluate if b holds **and** evaluate if c holds, even if (a == false). (This is possibly something that Java could improve in their compiler though. They probably have their reasons not to though.)

In this case, a is defined as (mc.thePlayer != null) and c is defined as (!mc.thePlayer.isSneaking())
The way it WAS formulated, Java would evaluate the (!mc.thePlayer.isSneaking()) statement even if (mc.thePlayer == null), see my previous statement.

I agree that my code looks like a messy workaround, but I tried to not duplicate code and keeping that in mind, this sounded like the simplest solution to:
1. Make sure that the isSneaking() method is only called if thePlayer is not null.
2. Keep the logic expression intact.

If you can solve the bug, because there definitely is one, and at the mean time keep the total logic expression intact **and** the code clean. Then by all means, show me how.

NOTE:
You should look at the second commit. The first commit was wrong and I know.
a && b will only evaluate B should A be true. a || b will only evaluate B
should A be false.

Also, two messy commits, with a bad comment? Rebase it into one for ANY
chance of merge.

Squash your commits down to one please
Also since this is so big it'd be nice if we could have someone else knowledgeable look over it as well
Oh I just looked at the lang file..

If you have not translated something, do not include it in the ja-JP lang file, it will be inherited from en_US automatically. If you copy it, then it will desync - if en_US gets updated then the copy in ja-JP will be outdated and potentially translated incorrectly later down the line.

TLDR: Only include the lines that are actually in Japanese, leave anything out that you haven't translated.

This will also let the patch size not be enormous -.-
I don't think the other lang files follow this rule exactly, but no better time to start :P
OK, I got it. I'll correct the file.

comments:
Arg! Didn't notice the merge commit. Please hold.
Actually, I can't seem to rebase that merge commit - I did `git rebase -i origin/lex-botania-lang_en-corrections lex-botania-lang_en-corrections` and it pulled in the "corrected spelling & grammar" etc. commit and then jumped to the commit ("fixed a typo") BEFORE the merge commit. This is not my first time squashing commits, but I honestly have no idea what's going on with this. I think the situation may have gotten confused because I updated my branch with the latest from upstream/master between commits.
try squashing by commit sha1 (`git rebase -i ea10c48439082814e32f1bbc610d7ab31242bb30`)
Okay, there we go - turned out the problem was git apparently does not like the way Sublime Text 3 handles file streams or something, because it would open the "interactive" text file and then git would immediately act as if I'd saved and closed the file, resulting in a completely empty commit that just made things worse. I changed my system to use notepad as the default .txt file handler and rebased again, and this time got the expected results.
you don't use vim to do it when git brings it up?
Nope, not that hardcore. Used to be pretty proficient with emacs back in
high school, though.

Refactors the three classes in `client.challenge` by adding comments and removing warnings. Not too much to say, really, other than check over the diff. There may be several of these types of PRs over the next few days, as they are a lot less about coding and a lot more about documentation.

(Adding comments makes me feel better).

Also, challenges still work, of course:

![2016-01-15_19 35 04](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12369605/52f87aae-bbc0-11e5-9ea7-d92671a8aa82.png)

Followup on PR #1750, which thanks to @williewillus 's input, changes the means of concurrency to explicit sidedness instead of just concurrent data structures (as lovely as they may be).

This actually makes for a notable difference in single player, as the block swapper is no longer duplicated on both the local client and server (saving a respectable amount of duplicate computation).

As usual, proof of working for both the Terra Axe and Pasture Seed - tested both on single player and multiplayer:

![2016-01-15_18 04 33](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12368947/6d758a70-bbb6-11e5-820a-9c0375d6f276.png)
![2016-01-15_18 04 38](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12368946/6d75382c-bbb6-11e5-80a6-bcc2b790b3c2.png)
![2016-01-15_18 05 31](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12368948/6d76131e-bbb6-11e5-9642-4569644feb6b.png)
![2016-01-15_18 05 39](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12368949/6d76db64-bbb6-11e5-80e7-e3e7d1b343b5.png)

Note that the solution simply employs remote checks, which works fine in principle. If I revisit this class for a clean up, however, a proper server and client proxy (where the client only handles visual effects and the server does most of the actual work) would definitely first in my priority list. Comments welcome.
comments: Proxies would be unnecessary, remote checks would be the standard way to do this kind of stuff.

body:
Changes the `HashMap`/`ArrayList` map used by both BlockSwappers in `ItemGrassSeed` and `ItemTerraAxe` to a `ConcurrentHashMap` and `ConcurrentHashMap`-backed set instead, which ensures that crazy threading issues do not cause esoteric NPEs and iterator invalidation.

No functional changes occurred, and performance should be equivalent.

The Terra Axe still murders trees:

![2016-01-14_22 12 38](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12345663/c2d86046-bb11-11e5-8365-b691b3d9d8c4.png)
![2016-01-14_22 12 52](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12345664/c2e68c3e-bb11-11e5-9f88-5650c3cedb35.png)

The Pasture Seed still unmurders grass:

![2016-01-14_22 13 54](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12345669/cc6f7ad6-bb11-11e5-9b11-6aaefb5468b6.png)
![2016-01-14_22 14 10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12345668/cc6f3bac-bb11-11e5-8699-d47a5129d003.png)

This provides the straightforward solution as outlined in #1722, by allowing the client to also handle slowdowns. The existing code allowed the client to handle the actual speedup, but prevented it from reseting the speed as well due to a remote server check. The actual origin of the bug is related to `Entity.moveForward` always being `0.0F` on the server, but the fix for it is nontrivial and this will work as a working solution in the meanwhile.

With this patch, the sash properly resets it's speed both on the client and the server if the user stops for a few moments. The sash speeds up properly as it already has been.

Comments welcome.

body:
This fixes the subtly buggy, existing breadth first search implementation by replacing it with a much more rigorous Djikstra-based Breadth First Search (which optimizes use of available range). The axe will now take advantage of the full 32 block range and respect leaves as reducing range to 3 properly, and will no longer eat entire canopies. This also comes with a nice speed boost, as only 1 block swapper needs to be created and the search can be done in amortized O(nlogn) time (where n is the number of candidate blocks).

Here are some pictures of the results:

An unassuming jungle:
![2016-01-13_03 36 07](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12290574/30a54654-b9a8-11e5-87f0-733737e724da.png)

Complete destruction of two trees, save some dangling leaves - previously, the top part of the tree would remain:
![2016-01-13_03 36 25](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12290609/4c514a92-b9a8-11e5-8f98-51a28c6a4e5f.png)
![2016-01-13_03 36 38](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12290613/4f21975e-b9a8-11e5-8720-96743583e0eb.png)

Another example on some poor, poor Spruce trees:
![2016-01-13_03 39 20](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12290624/58594ac4-b9a8-11e5-98d7-908dc6d5c973.png)

![2016-01-13_03 39 29](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12290626/5be2929a-b9a8-11e5-882c-057396868385.png)

![2016-01-13_03 39 33](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/616490/12290627/5e3a7e36-b9a8-11e5-9f40-3a2e11e144b9.png)

No effects on unconnected trees.

As you can see, there are some new constants. Any comments on the constants or the PR are of course welcome. I didn't notice any regressions when using the axe otherwise, and mana use, FX and so forth were all maintained (I didn't touch any of that, anyway).

body: Corrects the issue where the Rod of Shifting Crust would not replace blocks surrounded by snow or other specific non-opaque cubes (eg, slabs). Blocks are checked for visibility by checking if there are any adjacent blocks which do not have an adjacent solid side.

There isn't much of a unit testing base here, of course, but it functions equivalently when there are no snow-like or slab-like blocks around. When there are, it takes whether or not the block is actually visible into account. I'll give you a few screenshots.

Using cobblestone as the material we're swapping to. Used on a standard homogenous surface (with default range and so forth):

Adds UUID support for relics. 

Everything should work fine, both with items that have UUID and for those that doesn't. If an item has both UUID and username information, it will prefer the UUID, if not it will fall back to using the username. Username will be converted to UUID when the owner has the item in his inventory.

body:
It started with "ubiquitous", and ended in AAAAAAAAAAAAAA. :)

This is a rough first-pass correction of typos, misspellings, grammar, comma-spliced run-on sentences, awkward or misleading phrasing, and some malapropism and catachresis that wasn't obviously a deliberate stylistic choice. This is by no means a comprehensive revision, and is just the most visible errors I noticed on first reading (at least 236 according to GitHub, or 382 by diffchecker.com).

Github's diff-checking appears to be overwhelmed by this quantity of edits, so you'll need to use an external tool to actually see the line-by-line changes.

Further corrections are certainly possible, but the process might stray too far towards "rewriting", rather than merely "cleaning up". As it stands, I've attempted to preserve the structure and content of the original text as much as possible.

This should be looked over by the original author before merging, for the following reasons:
- To ensure that I haven't "fixed" anything that wasn't deliberately "mis-written" for stylistic effect or to preserve a memetic reference.
- To pass judgement on a few "errors" that I noticed but did not change, for various reasons, listed below.
- To make sure I haven't "fixed" something wrongly. I'm not a professional writer; I have made, can make, and likely will make mistakes of my own.

Issues Not Corrected (but should be looked at):
- "Soujourner" should be "Sojourner", but this may be an intentional misspelling.
- In the Bellethorne entry, the word "malevelous" - is that supposed to be "Marvelous", "Malevolent", or a deliberate portmanteau?
- "Simpleton" is a _noun_, describing a "simple" person, with an emphasis on "person". The word is (mis?)used in place of the _adjective_ "Simple". Stylistic affectation, or error?
- "Message from Elven Garde" and "Elven Lore" texts. There were several apparent "errors", but Elves may have their own grammatical/syntactic quirks, due to who-knows-how-many-thousands of years of isolation and linguistic drift, followed by an Elvish-to-English translation likely done with no native English speakers at hand. In essence, the "mistakes" might be part of the lore.
Aditional Dadelifeons
The 2 variables are always assigned in the code below - so the initial assignment is not needed.

Two changes here:
- Generation 0 cells in the exclusion zone don't count as neighbors. Essentially, they are now truly "illegal cells" as implied in the Lexica Botania.
- When a new cell is blocked by an existing block, the Dandelifeon shuts down instead of ignoring that cell.

First the optimizations: Doing the same checks over and over is unhealthy. Its preferred to have a uglier but more efficient code like in writeToPacketNBT.

The possible fix, in the linkCollector you could end up with the linkCollector a null and the needsNew at false. All it was needed was for the cached coords to be invalid and not returning a block. Also, when reading theNBT packet, if the coords are 0,-1,0 just set the cache to null. Its an invalid cache coord, no need to force a call to the world that will fail returning a block.
Hopefully fixes a memory leak; see https://github.com/CatDany/Botania/commit/a629ce25f8946e633757495a65afe68f108b5286#commitcomment-11601022

body: I flip flopped the flippy floops in the flippity flop!
May fix https://github.com/Vazkii/Botania/issues/879

I am the current maintainer of akkamaddi's Additions to Simple Ores, and a user of Alexndr's Simple Ores2. This pull request adds almost all of Simple Ores2 & akkamaddi's Additions ores to the orechid and orechid ignem lists, with a few exceptions:

I excluded Simple Cobalt's (from akkamaddi's Additions) "oreCobalt", to avoid conflicting with and unbalancing anything relying on TiC's cobalt; Simple Cobalt's cobalt is an uncommon overworld ore, vs TiC's cobalt which is a rare nether ore. I excluded Simple Ores Netherrocks' "oreIllumenite" because it spawns in glowstone, not netherrack.  Finally, I excluded Simple Cthon's (another akkamaddi Addition) cthon ore, because I have deliberately not ore-dictionaried it to avoid grinder/pulveriser/etc machines from automatically adding ore->dust => smelt to ingot recipes--that would bypass how cthon ore is supposed to be refined in its original mod.  Addresses issue #875.

Finally, your SubTileEntity class file was mis-spelled and would not build. I fixed that.

@Vazkii has just created a chat room. You can visit it here: [https://gitter.im/Vazkii/Botania](https://gitter.im/Vazkii/Botania?utm_source=badge&utm_medium=badge&utm_campaign=pr-badge&content=body_link).

This pull-request adds this badge to your README.md:

[![Gitter](https://badges.gitter.im/Join%20Chat.svg)](https://gitter.im/Vazkii/Botania?utm_source=badge&utm_medium=badge&utm_campaign=pr-badge&utm_content=body_badge)

If my aim is a little off, please [let me know](https://github.com/gitterHQ/readme-badger/issues).

Happy chatting.

PS: [Click here](https://gitter.im/settings/badger/opt-out) if you would prefer not to receive automatic pull-requests from Gitter in future.

LightningHandler.onRenderWorldLast() modifies the model/view matrix and should therefore save and restore it. Actually, it introduces round-off errors into the model/view matrix by translating to world coordinates and back (calls to GL11.glTranslated()) which are proportional to the world coordinates' values (distant coordinates like 29 million introduce quite significant errors). Not restoring the matrix therefore makes it hard for other mods to do rendering correctly at distant coordinates.

This fixes issue #531.

body:
This adds Not Enough Items integrations for the recipe types defined in the Botania API:
- Petal Apothecary (http://puu.sh/cnx7P/814d27bc47.jpg)
- Runic Altar (http://puu.sh/cnxc8/2b032f6bf7.jpg)
- Mana Pool, including catalysts (http://puu.sh/cnxQr/1f249ec501.jpg)
- Elven Trade, only works if the player has a Lexica Botania with Elven knowledge (http://puu.sh/cnxSj/c6eef6ff8a.jpg)

Note that this adds CodeChickenLib, CodeChickenCore and NotEnoughItems as dependencies. 
I've added those to the gradle build script and it should auto-download them when setting up a workspace with it, but I'm not sure if that works with the 'proper' way of working with the build script. You might have to fix that.

body:
This is to fix a perceived exploit/oversight and is based on assumptions from the in-game descriptions as well as impressions about intended mod design. Basically, it is possible to create a mana transfer chain using dominant sparks that is extendable to arbitrary lengths. Basic sparks sending mana never fail the if statement and so never remove the dominant spark from their transfers list even when they are upgraded to dominant themselves. It should now only allow basic sparks to send to dominants, and recessive sparks to send to basic and dispersive. I know the basic->dominant transfers were the only ones that got put in the list, but it never hurts to be thorough.

Consider this an issue report with one possible way of fixing it attached.

body:
Turned of all particles when the in game setting is set minimal.

I know there is a config file to do this, but surly they shouldn't spawn when set to minimal.

This is helpful when I am playing on my laptop witch only get around 20 fps. I saw a 8 fps boost doing this.
Also, moar references. This is totally your fault.
commit_messages: Merge 62e8a47b7d48acd6a46860dd61fc0d3e9d880ef8 into 8fde7c99c21172ba1cfe651352439c6b006a1d0b

body:
1. I was actually surprised I was able to translate roughly 50% of the references in the version check.
2. "Flügel Tiara" <-- See https://github.com/Vazkii/Botania/commit/d8e1f4ca3b24f60e67b8e9461cc443be0498b882#commitcomment-6526094 and https://github.com/Vazkii/Botania/commit/0453eeb28a8243a10c643df6e9ef4b4029968f2c#commitcomment-6526217 for comments.

The hydroangeas will now pick nearby blocks at random, instead of doing a for loop to decide what to check.
I did format it in idea, so you will need to redo that ;)

Changed the way uploads are handled and added an api and deobfuscated jars to the build. Removed the hard dependency to Baubles in the build.gradle as FG will automatically use it if its placed in a libs directory in the project root. I am currently working on the site I have a idea how to auto update it.
Maybe now I can finally automate it :)

Made this so developers can add Botania to their workspace without having to clone it.

On a side note why do you use an ANT build script when gradle could do it just as easy?

body: I see you already saw my comments on the code. I have branched botania just for this so I'll jump into spell-check to help you in any way that I can when needed. I even had to research how to branch to edit it... xD

Includes both structure NBT for gameplay (there might be a couple of unused structures, since everything except `gog_island` has been moved to Patchouli multiblocks quite a while ago) and SBNT for gametest.

(fixes #4602 for now)
